column2: Secure and ensure access to a range of quality seeds for plant varieties in order to adapt to the pressures of climate change.
column5: The implementation of TA5.12 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.38, as the development of climate-resilient crop varieties can contribute to the EU's offshore renewable energy goals by reducing the environmental impact of agriculture and increasing the availability of land for renewable energy production. This can help achieve the target of 60 GW of installed capacity by 2030.

column2: Reduce food waste
column5: The reduction of food waste in TA5.13 can have a positive impact on TA3.1, as it can lead to a decrease in the amount of waste generated and subsequently reduce the need for new raw materials, thereby supporting the circular economy and reducing waste management costs.

column2: Scale-up and promote sustainable and socially responsible production methods and circular business models in food processing and retail.
column5: The implementation of TA5.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.3, as the promotion of circular business models and sustainable production methods can contribute to the development of a more circular economy, reducing waste and the demand for primary raw materials.

column2: Reduce the environmental and climate footprint of the EU food system, operating within planetary boundaries.
column5: The reduction of the environmental and climate footprint of the EU food system in TA5.15 can have a positive impact on TA2.38, as it can lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions and support the development of renewable energy sources, such as offshore wind.

column2: ncome distribution: Ensure fair income and salaries.
column5: The implementation of TA5.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.12, as fair income distribution can lead to increased consumer spending and demand for sustainable products, supporting the development of a circular economy and the growth of sustainable industries.

column2: Sectorial growth: Help farmers and fishers to strengthen their position in the supply chain and to capture a fair share of the added value of sustainable production.
column5: The implementation of TA5.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.9, as strengthening the position of farmers and fishers in the supply chain can lead to increased investment in sustainable production methods and the development of new industries, supporting the growth of a circular economy.

column2: Market power and business structure: Improve agricultural rules that strengthen the position of farmers (e.g. producers of products with geographical indications), their cooperatives and producer organisations in the food supply chain.
column5: The implementation of TA5.18 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.11, as improving agricultural rules and strengthening the position of farmers can lead to increased diversification of the EU's imports of strategic raw materials, reducing dependence on a limited number of suppliers.

column2: Trade: Foster the competitiveness of the EU supply sector.
column5: The implementation of TA5.20 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.40, as fostering the competitiveness of the EU supply sector can lead to increased investment in renewable energy sources, such as hydrogen, and support the development of new industries.

column2: Digitalisation and knowledge transfer. Ensure access to fast broadband to all farmers and all rural areas to achieve the objective of 100% access by 2025
column5: The implementation of TA5.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.13, as ensuring access to fast broadband can support the development of digital technologies and the growth of sustainable industries, such as recycling and the production of sustainable raw materials.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials
column5: The implementation of TA5.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.16, as achieving high targets for material recovery can support the development of a circular economy and reduce the demand for primary raw materials.

column2: Social protection and poverty: Ensure fair, inclusive and ethical value chains.
column5: The implementation of TA5.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.19, as ensuring fair and inclusive value chains can lead to increased investment in sustainable production methods and the development of new industries, supporting the growth of a circular economy.

column2: Animal welfare: Promote better animal welfare to improve animal health and food quality.
column5: The implementation of TA5.25 may have a negative impact on TA3.1, as promoting better animal welfare can lead to increased costs for farmers and food producers, potentially impacting food prices and availability.

column2: Food messaging: Provide food information and labelling to empower consumers to make informed, healthy and sustainable food choices.
column5: The implementation of TA5.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.3, as providing clear food labelling and information can support the development of a circular economy and reduce food waste.

column2: Food availability: Improve availability of sustainable food.
column5: The implementation of TA5.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.9, as improving the availability of sustainable food can lead to increased investment in sustainable production methods and the development of new industries, supporting the growth of a circular economy.

column2: Food affordability: Ensure affordability to sufficient, nutritious and sustainable food.
column5: The implementation of TA5.30 may have a negative impact on TA3.1, as ensuring food affordability can lead to increased demand for food and potentially impact food prices and availability.

column2: Cumulative EU offshore goals of installed capacity: 60 GW by 2030 and 300 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.12, as the development of offshore renewable energy can support the development of climate-resilient crop varieties and reduce the environmental impact of agriculture.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of ocean energy by 2030 and 40 GW by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.39 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.14, as the development of ocean energy can support the promotion of circular business models and sustainable production methods in the food sector.

column2: Around 30% of EU primary steel production is expected to be decarbonised on the basis of renewable hydrogen.
column5: The implementation of TA2.40 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.17, as the development of renewable hydrogen can support the growth of sustainable industries and the development of new technologies, such as carbon capture and storage.

column2: Halve the amount of residual (non-recycled) municipal waste by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA3.1 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.13, as reducing municipal waste can lead to a decrease in food waste and support the development of a circular economy.

column2: Double EU’s circular material use rate in the coming decade
column5: The implementation of TA3.3 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.14, as increasing the circular material use rate can support the development of circular business models and sustainable production methods in the food sector.

column2: By 2030, Union extraction capacity should be able to extract the ores, minerals or concentrates needed to produce at least 10% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials
column5: The implementation of TA3.8 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.18, as increasing the Union's extraction capacity can support the development of strategic raw materials and reduce dependence on external suppliers.

column2: By 2030, Union processing capacity, including for all intermediate processing steps, should be able of producing at least 40% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials
column5: The implementation of TA3.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.17, as increasing the Union's processing capacity can support the growth of sustainable industries and the development of new technologies, such as carbon capture and storage.

column2: Diversify the Union’s imports of strategic raw materials with a view to ensuring that, by 2030, the Union’s annual consumption of each strategic raw material at any relevant stage of processing can rely on imports from several third countries or from overseas countries or territories (OCTs) and that no third country accounts for more than 65% of the Union’s annual consumption of such a strategic raw material
column5: The implementation of TA3.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.20, as diversifying the Union's imports can support the development of strategic raw materials and reduce dependence on external suppliers.

column2: By 2030, manufacturing capacity in the Union of the strategic net-zero technologies listed in the Annex approaches or reaches a benchmark of at least 40% of the Union’s annual deployment needs
column5: The implementation of TA3.12 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.21, as increasing the manufacturing capacity can support the development of digital technologies and the growth of sustainable industries.

column2: By 2030, Union recycling capacity, including for all intermediate recycling steps, should be able of producing at least 25% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials and should be able of recycling significantly increasing amounts of each strategic raw material from waste
column5: The implementation of TA3.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.22, as increasing the recycling capacity can support the development of a circular economy and reduce the demand for primary raw materials.
